data.title: Unable to installing atom-amd64.deb on Ubuntu 17.04
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Unable to install atom on ubuntu 17.04
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Download .deb package from atom.io on Ubuntu 17.04(a clean install is best for repro)
2. Double click to open the deb package on Ubuntu Software Store  
3. Click install

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Atom installs


**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Nothing happens


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%


**MORE INFO:**
If you attempt to install on terminal via `sudo dpkg -i atom-amd64.deb `
you get the following errors:
```
dpkg: dependency problems prevent configuration of atom:
 atom depends on git; however:
  Package git is not installed.
 atom depends on gconf2; however:
  Package gconf2 is not installed.
 atom depends on gconf-service; however:
  Package gconf-service is not installed.
```
If you try to start Atom after failed to install, you get
```
/usr/share/atom/atom: error while loading shared libraries: libgconf-2.so.4: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```
If you run ` sudo apt --fix-broken install` this fixes the issue and atom starts working.

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS: Ubuntu 17.04
**uname -a:**
```
Linux ubuntu 4.10.0-19-generic #21-Ubuntu SMP Thu Apr 6 17:04:57 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Opening any file with atom leads to opening atom with empty state
data.body:
If i just open atom by clicking on the desktop exe short, it opens blank state, which is fine. I can open any file I want by ctrl+O or drag&drop from a file explorer program.

However, if I open a file with atom, for example "test.cpp" file, atom will proceed to open the blank state.
This happens with any file I open with atom. 

Is this a bug?

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Invalid Point: (NaN, 0)
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: 
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

For some files the text doesn't even load. For others it loads but gives the error below when steps below are followed. Files where the text doesn't load also do this. If the file is closed and reopened without loading the window it works fine. On reload it always happens again. I couldn't reproduce in safe mode.

```
TypeError: Invalid Point: (NaN, 0)
    at Function.module.exports.Point.assertValid (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/point.js:63:15)
    at DisplayLayer.translateScreenPosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/display-layer.js:326:11)
    at DisplayMarkerLayer.module.exports.DisplayMarkerLayer.translateScreenPosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/display-marker-layer.js:163:32)
    at DisplayMarker.module.exports.DisplayMarker.setHeadScreenPosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/text-buffer/lib/display-marker.js:154:52)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/cursor.js:72:31
    at Cursor.module.exports.Cursor.changePosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/cursor.js:684:7)
    at Cursor.module.exports.Cursor.setScreenPosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/cursor.js:70:19)
    at /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1902:23
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.moveCursors (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:2125:9)
    at TextEditor.module.exports.TextEditor.setCursorScreenPosition (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor.js:1901:19)
    at TextEditorComponent.module.exports.TextEditorComponent.onMouseDown (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:721:25)
    at HTMLDivElement.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/text-editor-component.js:3:59)
```

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Reload the window with an affected file open (I haven't figured out which files are affected)
2. Click anywhere in the editor
3. error pops up

### Versions

```
~ ❯ atom -v 
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
~ ❯ apm -v
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0
```

data.title: Fix SyntaxError while building v1.16.0 release on Ubuntu 17.04 i686
data.body:
Fix **SyntaxError** while building v1.16.0 release on Ubuntu 17.04 i686 with `./script/build --create-debian-package`

```
~/atom/script/lib/code-sign-on-mac.js:13
  let certPath = process.env.ATOM_MAC_CODE_SIGNING_CERT_PATH;
    ^^^

    SyntaxError: Block-scoped declarations (let, const, function, class) not yet supported outside strict mode
```

Thank's to @yvan-sraka for it's helpful debug!

data.title: Precompiled binary 'mksnapshot' breaks building process (Centos 6.x).
data.body:
Hi,
Starting with 1.17.0, the building process on a Centos 6.x machine is not working anymore.
Everything is crashing on snapshot creation:
..............
Verifying if snapshot can be executed via `mksnapshot`
Generating startup blob at "atom-1.17.0-beta4/out/snapshot_blob.bin"

atom-1.17.0-beta4/script/node_modules/electron-mksnapshot/bin/mksnapshot: /usr/lib64/libstdc++.so.6: version `GLIBCXX_3.4.15' not found (required by atom-1.17.0-beta4/script/node_modules/electron-mksnapshot/bin/mksnapshot)

Error: Command failed: atom-1.17.0-beta4/script/node_modules/electron-mksnapshot/bin/mksnapshot atom-1.17.0-beta4/out/startup.js --startup_blob atom-1.17.0-beta4/out/snapshot_blob.bin
............
It seems that with this version, the building procedure calls a PRECOMPILED BINARY 'mksnapshot', not compiled during the building stage as other tools as before. By using a precompiled tool during building process, the portability is broken. I have no problems to run 'atom' in a different root environment (avoiding `GLIBCXX_3.4.15' not found` issues), but I cannot do this during the building procedure.

System: Centos 6.x (supported until the end of 2020).
atom: v1.17.0-beta4
nodejs: v6.10.3
npm: v3.10.10

I am not happy with precompiled tools during building process (like electron-mksnapshot), I consider this as a bad decision. It should be compiled during building process, not using precompiled binaries.

data.title: Disable zoom only after the window has finished loading
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/14252.

Previously, we were disabling the zoom functionality right when creating an `AtomWindow` instance, which doesn't work possibly due to `webContents` not being ready yet.

With this pull request we will disable zooming in/out only after receiving the `window:loaded` event from the renderer process.

/cc: @ungb @iolsen

data.title: Autoreloading changed files does not work with multiple files
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->
### Description

The automatic reloading of files which have changed only works reliable without many tabs.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open one file with atom.
2. Change it external. (you should see the changed version in atom)
3. Open 3 more files with atom.
4. Redo step 2. (the chance is high that atom misses the update and shows the old version of the file)

**Expected behavior:** Atom should always show the current state of the file opened.

**Actual behavior:** Atom misses updates of opened files and sometimes shows old states.

**Reproduces how often:** It misses 9/10 updates with 4 tabs open.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

I only used normal txt files with 20-50 lines each. And Im using windows 7 64bit.

data.title: Memory explode!
data.body:
I connected the Kite for Atom. And when I open a python script and import a package, say SNAP(a python package for Social Network), and after several minutes, the memory of my mac just explode, increased from a normal level to an extremely high level. I don't know if this is a bug of Atom.

I tried to shut down the Kite, and reopened my python file, and everything is good. Nothing abnormal. And I also tried to open other python scripts, and it is good as well.

Therefore, I guess this might be the problems of Atom, Kite, and some special python packages. From the perspective of Atom, could you give me some advice?

The screenshot is as follow:
![atom_memory](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15654140/25695571/8a54b972-3068-11e7-85a6-177c9031ba48.jpeg)

data.title: Minor changes to compile-cache.js for atom-in-orbit.
data.body:
Currently, atom-in-orbit's build script has a step
where it applies these changes locally using a patch file,
which is gross. By upstreaming what atom-in-orbit needs
exported, we can remove this gross hack.

I tested this with the complementary change to atom-in-orbit
and verified that the new build worked properly.

Released under CC0.

### Description of the Change

This exports some symbols from `src/compile-cache.js` that
are needed by the https://github.com/facebooknuclide/atom-in-orbit project.

### Alternate Designs

Currently, atom-in-orbit works around this using a gross hack:
https://github.com/facebooknuclide/atom-in-orbit/blob/302363fc34936511526a0cb11f20628215317d7b/scripts/build.js#L55-L59

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This is the only way to export this functionality to other tools.

### Benefits

Admittedly, the future of the atom-in-orbit project is still up in the air,
but at some point, it would be nice to invest more in a web-only version of Atom.

### Possible Drawbacks

It's a little weird to export some symbols that are not used by other files
in Atom itself.

### Applicable Issues

I didn't file an issue, but the project's README calls out the current jankiness:
https://github.com/facebooknuclide/atom-in-orbit/blame/302363fc34936511526a0cb11f20628215317d7b/README.md#L154-L156

data.title: Ensure binary compatibility checks with/without the module cache are consistent
data.body:
The binary compatibility check normally only looks at `.node` files inside `build/Release`. However, the check with the cached `_atomModuleCache` looks at _all_ `.node` files no matter where they are.

This can cause all sorts of issues depending on where the `.node` files are. Since `_atomModuleCache` blindly indexes all files in the package, this can false-alarm on incompatible binaries even if they're never required.

With and without --safe my Shell load time is always above 2000ms

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: The editor is not responding.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In many different cases the Atom editor will report "The editor is not responding" shortly after launch.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Upgrade Atom
2. Launch Atom

or

1. Update Windows
2. Launch Atom

or

1. Update packages
2. Restart Atom

**Expected behavior:**
Atom should open properly

**Actual behavior:**
Atom freezes during the load and then says "The editor is not responding."

**Reproduces how often:**
Probably 50-75% of Atom upgrades. 100% of major Windows upgrades (Creators Update was the last one that caused it). 10% of package upgrades.

### Versions
Atom 1.16.0
Windows 10 Pro x64 (Creator's Update)

### Additional Information

atom --clear-window-state resolves this 100% of the time for me when it occurs.

data.title: Go to beginning of line doesn't work with soft wrapped lines
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When on a soft wrapped line pressing "Home" on windows brings the cursor to the start of the text but pressing it again does not move the cursor (and especially the view) to the beginning of the line

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a line that atom will soft wrap
2. Have the cursor on the soft wrapped line with the view scrolled somewhat away from the left side
3. Press the Home key twice, the cursor will move to the start of the wrapped code and the view will go to only just beyond that

**Expected behavior:** 
The view to move all the way to the left side and or the cursor to move the left as well

**Actual behavior:** 
Nothing, the cursor and view stay at the end of the displayed text

**Reproduces how often:** 
100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

data.title: Regex backreference in replace field (of find and replace) does not respect syntax to separate the backreference from immediately following number literal
data.body:
### Description

When I try to use a backreference followed by a number literal, the expected correct syntax does not work and is instead taken as a literal itself. For example, ${1}4 does not result in the first backreference being followed by a 4, but rather the literal string "${1}4". 

The last paragraph (two sentences) in the first section at the following link describes the behavior I expect:
http://www.regular-expressions.info/replacebackref.html

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a value in the editor like "1, 2, 3"
2. Press CTRL+F and turn on regex search
3. Paste in the pattern (\d, \d, )\d, and make sure it matches correctly
4. Now, in the replace field past in the pattern ${1}4
5. Note that the highlighting looks like all literals, with no highlighting to indicate a backreference (remove the curly braces to see what I mean, then replace them.)
6. Do the replace, note the unexpected result of "${1}4"

**Expected behavior:** When I have a backreference that needs to be immediately followed by a number literal, I expect wrapping the backreference's number in curly braces to isolate it from any immediately following number literals. For example, ${1}4 should give me the value of the first backreference followed immediately by a 4.

**Actual behavior:** replace string ${1}4 replaces the found text with the literal string "${1}4", completely ignoring the backreference, when curly braces are added.

**Reproduces how often:** Every attempted use of this pattern.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

I don't have any packages installed which should have anything to do with this part of Atom's functionality. This appears to be the default behavior of the current code base.

data.title: Build and install locally does not work. Ubuntu 16.04

data.title: Simple account
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode

This should probably go into a beta hotfix.

data.title: Focus taken away when dock was hidden( not respect original activeElement ).
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When dock was hidden, it **force** focus on workspaceCenter's active pane( Ignore original focus ).

https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/14143/commits/73f04fdaed30b774d1f5134a1df05eba30202aab

So hiding dock means "focus is taken away from originally focused element".
I want hiding dock not cause focus change unless hidden dock was originally focused.

When package-author try to implement action which hide dock and want to keep focus on `select-list` or mini-editor.
It's unnecessarily difficult since hiding dock force focus to workspaceCenter's active pane.

- Actual situation

In my [project-folder](https://atom.io/packages/project-folder) package, user can add/remove multiple project with keeping focus on select-list.
The `space` key in `select-list` is keymapped as "confirm and continue" action which confirm current item on select-list and keep focus on `select-list` so that user can continuously remove/add project folder.
From atom v1.17(which introduced dock), when project paths get emptied, tree-view destroy itself and tree-view's dock is hidden.
At this point, **focus is taken away from select-list to workspaceCenter's active pane** and `blur` event is fired on `select-list`'s element. which cause `cancel()` of select-list.
I don't want `cancel`, or `blur`, just want focus kept on originally focused `selec-list`'s mini-editor.

This is new issue from atom v1.17.0. Was not problem in v1.16.0.

https://github.com/t9md/atom-project-folder/issues/9#issuecomment-298679687

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set following commands and keymap.

- `init.coffee`

```coffeescript
atom.commands.add 'atom-workspace',
  'user:focus-taken-away-repro': ->
    for dir in atom.project.getPaths()
      atom.project.removePath(dir)
```

- `keymap.cson`

```coffeescript
'.select-list':
  'space': 'user:focus-taken-away-repro'
```

2. Start atom-beta(v1.17) with at least one project-folder listed on tree-view.
3. `cmd-t` to start `fuzzy-finder`.
4. type `space`, which invoke `user:focus-taken-away-repro` comands.

- In atom 1.16.0: focus remain in `select-list`'s mini-editor.
- In atom 1.17.0-beta3: focus taken away from `select-list` to activePane.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Want atom not take away original focus when dock was hidden.
Want keep focused on `select-list`'s mini-editor.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Original focus was taken away from `select-list` to activePane.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%, allways.

### Versions

```coffeescript
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta3
Electron: 1.3.14
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Strange background-color artifacts in TextEditor in Atom 1.17-beta4
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
In Atom 1.17-beta4, the text editor shows strange background color artifacts when Atom is shown on an external monitor:

![atom-1-17-screen-issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/632968/25613273/8c0502de-2f25-11e7-9673-e1cf9d09e69d.gif)

These artifacts don't show up on my macbook's retina display; only on the external monitor (In the gif above, you can see me dragging the Atom window from my retina screen to the external monitor.

The issue goes away if I remove either the `transform` or `background-color` properties of the 6-line `<div/>` element in the text editor. The artifacts also seem to be influenced by the cursor position. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom Beta on external monitor
2. text editor shows artifacts
3. Moving the cursor will change the artifacts

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100% under the above conditions

data.title: Atom for windows can`t install
data.body: I used the "AtomSetup-x64.exe" and it said " Failed to extract installer".

data.title: Search (Find in project) has strange behaviour
data.body:
### Prerequisites
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Whenever I seach in my project files, there is a strange and incorrect difference between a normal 'Find in project' search and entering a project folder to search into.

I have two project folders in Atom. When search and leave the path field empty, it is done in about a second and returns an X number of search results.
When I then search within the directory of just one of the projects, the search takes much longer and returns many more results. What i looks like (but there are too many files and folders to be able to make sure), is that when I search within a project directory, it also searches within greyed out subfolders, so folders that are supposed to be excluded from the search. The option 'Exclude VCS ignored paths' is ticked.
I have a .gitignore and .dockerignore file in the project root directory that lists the subfolders that should be ignored.

I updated Atom to the newest version (1.16.0) and removed all packages that aren't there by default. I checked with someone else who is using 1.12.0 and he has the same issue.

data.title: Bump apm to 1.18.1
data.body:
:arrow_up: apm@1.18.1

Includes:

* https://github.com/atom/apm/pull/714
* https://github.com/atom/apm/pull/716

/cc @smashwilson @damieng

data.title: Module version mismatch expected 49, got 48
data.body:
I'm trying to develop some features for language-capnproto package. and I added `bignum` node module as a dependency.

**Atom**: 1.16.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.3.13
**OS**: Ubuntu 16.04
**Thrown From**: [language-capnproto](https://github.com/tekacs/language-capnproto) package 0.3.0


### Stack Trace

Failed to activate the language-capnproto package

```
At Module version mismatch. Expected 49, got 48.

Error: Module version mismatch. Expected 49, got 48.
    at Error (native)
    at process.module.(anonymous function) (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:168:20)
    at process.module.(anonymous function) [as dlopen] (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:168:20)
    at Object.Module._extensions..node (module.js:583:18)
    at Object.module.(anonymous function) [as .node] (ELECTRON_ASAR.js:168:20)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
    at /packages/language-capnproto/node_modules/bignum/index.js:4:11)
    at Module._compile (/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:109:30)
    at /app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:216:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
    at /packages/language-capnproto/lib/capnp.coffee:2:27)
    at /packages/language-capnproto/lib/capnp.coffee:1:1)
    at Module._compile (/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:109:30)
    at /app.asar/src/compile-cache.js:216:21)
    at Module.load (module.js:473:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:432:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:424:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:483:17)
    at require (/app.asar/src/native-compile-cache.js:50:27)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.requireMainModule (/app.asar/src/package.js:796:27)
    at Package.module.exports.Package.activateNow (/app.asar/src/package.js:207:16)
    at /app.asar/src/package.js:190:32
```

### Non-Core Packages

```
atom-beautify 0.29.17 
atom-material-ui 1.3.9 
autocomplete-python 1.8.12 
git-plus 7.0.7 
hyperclick 0.0.40 
language-capnproto 0.3.0 
linter 1.11.18 
linter-flake8 2.1.3 
linter-python 3.0.5 
linter-python-pyflakes 0.1.0 
markdown-preview-plus 2.4.0 
python-indent 1.0.2 
python-tools 0.6.9 
terminal-fusion 2.4.2 
```
